commands.name: touch
commands.description:
The touch command in Linux is used to create new empty files or update the access and modification timestamps of existing files. It's commonly used to:
1) Create new empty files quickly
2) Update file timestamps without modifying content
3) Ensure files exist before other operations
4) Set specific timestamps for files

The command works by updating the file's access time (atime), modification time (mtime), and change time (ctime) to the current time by default.

-a.name: Access Time Only
-a.description: Update only the access time of the file, not the modification time

-c.name: No Create
-c.description: Do not create the file if it does not exist. Only update timestamps of existing files

-d.name: Custom Date/Time
-d.description: Use specified date/time string instead of current time. Accepts various date formats

-h.name: Dereference Symbolic Links
-h.description: Affect the target of symbolic links instead of the links themselves (when supported)

-m.name: Modification Time Only
-m.description: Update only the modification time, not the access time

-r.name: Reference File
-r.description: Use the timestamps from a reference file instead of current time

no_flags.output: Creates 'file.txt' if it doesn't exist, or updates its timestamps to current time if it exists

-a.output: Updates only the access time of 'logfile.txt' to current time without changing modification time

-c.output: No file is created. If 'nonexistent.txt' doesn't exist, nothing happens

-d.output: Sets all timestamps of 'file.txt' to January 15, 2024, 2:30 PM

-h.output: Updates timestamps of the file that symlink_to_file points to

-m.output: Updates only the modification time of 'document.pdf' to current time

-r.output: Sets timestamps of 'target.txt' to match those of 'source.txt'

--help.output: Displays comprehensive help information about touch command usage and options

--version.output: Displays version information of the touch command

--no-dereference.output: Treats 'mysymlink' as a regular file regardless of whether it's a symbolic link

commands.name: 7z
commands.description: 7-Zip is a high-compression file archiver supporting multiple formats including, ZIP, GZIP, TAR, and more. It features LZMA and LZMA2 compression algorithms offering high compression ratios, strong AES-256 encryption, self-extracting archives, and multi-volume archive support. It's a command-line alternative to GUI archive managers with extensive options for compression, extraction, testing, and archive management.

a.name: Add to archive
a.description: Add files to archive or create new archive. This is the primary command for creating or modifying archives.

d.name: Delete from archive
d.description: Delete files from archive. Removes specified files from an existing archive.

e.name: Extract
e.description: Extract files from archive (without directory structure). Files are extracted to current directory without preserving folder hierarchy.

x.name: Extract with full paths
x.description: Extract files from archive with full paths. Preserves the complete directory structure as stored in the archive.

l.name: List contents
l.description: List contents of archive. Shows detailed information about files in archive including size, compression ratio, date, and attributes.

t.name: Test archive
t.description: Test integrity of archive. Verifies that archive is not corrupted and all files can be extracted correctly.

u.name: Update archive
u.description: Update files to archive. Adds files that are newer or don't exist in the archive.

b.name: Benchmark
b.description: Benchmark CPU and memory. Tests compression/decompression speed and memory usage with various algorithms.

i.name: Show information
i.description: Show information about supported formats. Lists all archive formats and codecs that 7-Zip supports.

rn.name: Rename files
rn.description: Rename files in archive. Changes names of files within the archive without extracting.

-t{format}.name: Archive type
-t{format}.description: Specify archive type. Determines the format of the archive to create or operate on.

-m{method}.name: Compression method
-m{method}.description: Set compression method. Controls the algorithm used for compression.

-mx{N}.name: Compression level
-mx{N}.description: Set compression level (0-9). Higher numbers give better compression but are slower.

-mhe.name: Header encryption
-mhe.description: Enable archive header encryption (7z format only). Encrypts file names and metadata.

-p{password}.name: Password
-p{password}.description: Set password for encryption/decryption. Secures archive with AES-256 encryption.

-o{dir}.name: Output directory
-o{dir}.description: Set output directory for extraction. Specifies where extracted files should be placed.

-r.name: Recurse subdirectories
-r.description: Recurse subdirectories. Processes all files in specified directory and its subdirectories.

-sfx.name: Create SFX archive
-sfx.description: Create self-extracting archive. Generates an executable that can extract itself without 7-Zip installed.

-v {size}.name: Create volumes
-v {size}.description: Create multi-volume archive. Splits archive into multiple parts of specified size.

-sdel.name: Delete after compression
-sdel.description: Delete files after adding to archive. Removes original files after successful compression.

-snl.name: Store symbolic links
-snl.description: Store symbolic links instead of following them. Preserves symlinks as links rather than copying target files.

-snh.name: Store hard links
-snh.description: Store hard links instead of following them. Preserves hard links rather than storing duplicate files.

commands.name: add-apt-repository
commands.description: The add-apt-repository command is used to add Personal Package Archives (PPA) repositories or other external repositories to the APT package management system's sources list. PPAs are software repositories hosted on Launchpad that allow developers to distribute software updates directly to Debian users. This command simplifies repository management by automatically fetching the GPG key, adding the repository to /etc/apt/sources.list.d/, and updating the package cache. It's commonly used to install software not available in official repositories or to get newer versions of packages.

--remove.name: Remove
--remove.description: Remove the specified repository from the system instead of adding it. This will delete the repository source file from /etc/apt/sources.list.d/ and update the package cache.

--yes.name: Automatic Yes
--yes.description: Automatically answer 'yes' to all prompts. This is useful for non-interactive scripts where user confirmation is not desired. It will automatically accept repository addition and GPG key import.

--no-update.name: No Update
--no-update.description: Do not update the package cache after adding the repository. This prevents automatic 'apt-get update' execution, allowing you to manually update later.

--enable-source.name: Enable Source
--enable-source.description: Also download the source repository for the specified PPA. This adds a 'deb-src' line to the sources, allowing source code downloading with 'apt-get source'.

--help.name: Help
--help.description: Display help information about the command usage and available options.

no_flags.output: Repository: 'deb http://ppa.launchpad.net/deadsnakes/ppa/ubuntu focal main' added to /etc/apt/sources.list.d/deadsnakes-ubuntu-ppa-focal.list. GPG key imported. Running 'apt update'...

remove.output: Repository 'ppa:deadsnakes/ppa' removed from /etc/apt/sources.list.d/deadsnakes-ubuntu-ppa-focal.list. Package cache updated.

yes.output: Repository added and GPG key imported automatically without prompts. Package cache updated.

no-update.output: Repository added to sources list. Note: Package cache NOT updated (use -n flag).

enable-source.output: Added both binary and source repositories. deb http://ppa.launchpad.net/git-core/ppa/ubuntu focal main and deb-src http://ppa.launchpad.net/git-core/ppa/ubuntu focal main

help.output:
Usage: add-apt-repository [OPTIONS] REPOSITORY

Options:
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  -m, --massive-debug   Print a lot of debug information to the command line
  -r, --remove          Remove the specified repository
  -y, --yes             Assume yes to all queries
  -n, --no-update       Do not update package cache after adding
  -s, --enable-source   Allow downloading of the source packages from the repository
  -c, --check           Check repository URL for validity before adding

commands.name: addpart
commands.description: addpart is a utility for informing the Linux kernel about the existence of a new partition on a block device. It does not modify the partition table on disk; it only tells the running kernel about the partition's existence. This is useful after creating a partition with tools that do not automatically inform the kernel, or when partitions are created on a device while the system is not running (e.g., on another system). The command is part of the util-linux package.

-h.name: Help
-h.description: Display a help message and exit.

--help.name: Help (long form)
--help.description: Display a help message and exit.

no_flags.output: No output on success. Informs the kernel that partition 1 exists on /dev/sdb, starting at sector 2048 with a length of 1048576 sectors.

commands.name: alias
commands.description: The alias command creates or lists temporary command aliases in the current shell session. An alias is a shortcut that maps a custom name to a longer command or command sequence, including arguments and options. Aliases created with this command are shell-specific and only persist for the duration of the current terminal session. To make aliases permanent, they must be added to shell startup files like ~/.bashrc, ~/.bash_aliases, or ~/.zshrc. Aliases are expanded before execution, and shell functions or scripts with the same name take precedence. The command can display existing aliases and their definitions when used without arguments or with the -p flag.

-p.name: Print Aliases
-p.description: Prints all currently defined aliases in a format that can be reused as input. The output displays each alias in the format 'alias NAME=VALUE', making it suitable for saving to a configuration file.

no_flags.output: Lists all currently defined aliases in the shell session

-p.output:
alias ll='ls -alF'
alias grep='grep --color=auto'
alias cls='clear'

commands.name: apt
commands.description: Advanced Package Tool (APT) is a package management system for Debian-based Linux distributions. It provides commands for installing, updating, upgrading, removing, and searching for software packages, as well as managing package repositories. APT handles dependencies automatically, fetching and installing all required packages.

install.name: Install packages
install.description: Installs one or more packages. The package names should be specified after the command. APT will automatically resolve and install dependencies.

remove.name: Remove packages
remove.description: Removes one or more installed packages while leaving configuration files on the system.

purge.name: Purge packages
purge.description: Completely removes one or more packages, including configuration files and other data associated with the package.

update.name: Update package lists
update.description: Downloads the latest package information from all configured repositories. This command does not install or upgrade any packages; it only updates APT's database of available packages.

upgrade.name: Upgrade packages
upgrade.description: Upgrades all installed packages to their latest available versions, based on the package lists last updated with 'apt update'. It does not remove packages or install new ones that weren't already installed.

full-upgrade.name: Full upgrade (dist-upgrade)
full-upgrade.description: Upgrades all installed packages, and may remove obsolete packages or install new dependencies as needed to complete the upgrade. This is more aggressive than 'upgrade' and is used for distribution upgrades.

autoremove.name: Auto remove
autoremove.description: Removes packages that were automatically installed to satisfy dependencies for other packages and are no longer needed.

search.name: Search packages
search.description: Searches the list of available packages for the given keyword in package names and descriptions.

show.name: Show package information
show.description: Displays detailed information about a specific package, including version, dependencies, size, and description.

list.name: List packages
list.description: Lists packages based on criteria. Without options, lists all available packages. Can be used with --installed or --upgradable.

edit-sources.name: Edit sources list
edit-sources.description: Opens the sources.list file and associated files in the default text editor for manual editing of repository configurations.

clean.name: Clean package cache
clean.description: Clears the local repository of retrieved package files, removing everything from the package cache (/var/cache/apt/archives).

autoclean.name: Auto clean package cache
autoclean.description: Removes package files from the cache that can no longer be downloaded (obsolete packages).

help.name: Display help
help.description: Displays a brief help message with common APT commands.

install.output: (Standard installation output showing package downloads and installation progress)

remove.output: (Standard removal output showing package removal progress)

purge.output: (Standard purge output showing complete removal including config files)

update.output: (Standard output showing repository updates and package list downloads)

upgrade.output: (Standard output showing packages to be upgraded and upgrade progress)

full-upgrade.output: (Standard output showing packages to be upgraded/removed/installed)

autoremove.output: (Standard output showing obsolete packages to be removed)

search.output: (List of packages matching 'texteditor' in name or description)

show.output: Detailed information for the vim package

list.output: (List of installed packages containing 'python' in their name)

edit-sources.output: Opens the default editor with the sources list file

clean.output: (No output on success, cache directory is emptied)

autoclean.output: (Output showing obsolete package files being removed)

commands.name: apt-cache
commands.description: apt-cache is a low-level command-line tool for querying information from APT's binary cache files. APT (Advanced Package Tool) is the package management system used by Debian, Ubuntu, and related Linux distributions. The cache contains metadata about available packages, their versions, dependencies, and descriptions, gathered from sources listed in `/etc/apt/sources.list` and files in `/etc/apt/sources.list.d/`. apt-cache does not install, remove, or modify packages; it is purely for querying information. It is essential for searching for packages, investigating dependencies, and checking package details before installation.

search.name: search
search.description: Searches the list of available package names for the given regular expression pattern. It performs a substring search on package names and their descriptions, returning a list of matches. The search is case-insensitive.

show.name: show
show.description: Displays detailed information about a specific package (or packages). This includes the package name, version, architecture, dependencies, size, maintainer, homepage, and a full description. If multiple package names are given, it shows info for each.

showpkg.name: showpkg
showpkg.description: Shows raw information about a package, focusing on its relationships. This includes a list of forward dependencies (what this package depends on), reverse dependencies (which packages depend on this one), and a list of available versions from the repository. It presents data in a more technical, dependency-focused format than `show`.

stats.name: stats
stats.description: Displays statistics about the APT cache. This includes the total number of package names, total number of package versions, total number of dependencies, total number of virtual packages, and the total size of the cache data.

policy.name: policy
policy.description: Displays the source priority configuration (pin preferences) for each package, or for a specified package. It shows which version would be installed from which repository based on priority, including candidate, installed, and version table. Crucial for understanding version pinning.

depends.name: depends
depends.description: Lists every package that the specified package depends on (its dependencies), recursively. It shows a tree of dependencies, including alternatives (e.g., `libc6 | libc6.1`). The output shows the dependency chain and which packages would satisfy each requirement.

rdepends.name: rdepends
rdepends.description: Lists every package that depends on the specified package (its reverse dependencies). It can be run recursively to show the full tree of packages that require the given package, either directly or indirectly.

pkgnames.name: pkgnames
pkgnames.description: Lists the names of all packages in the system, or only those starting with a given prefix. This command is useful for scripting or getting a quick list of available packages. Without a prefix, it outputs a very long list.

dotty.name: dotty
dotty.description: Generates a DOT-formatted graph of the dependency relationships between a set of packages. The output can be piped to a tool like `graphviz` to create a visual diagram. It requires one or more package names as arguments.

xvfb.name: xvfb
xvfb.description: An internal helper for `dotty`. It runs the `dotty` command in a virtual X server environment (Xvfb) to generate a PostScript file automatically. Rarely used directly by end-users.

dump.name: dump
dump.description: Dumps the entire contents of the cache as a raw, machine-readable list. It outputs a very large amount of data, showing every record in the cache. Used primarily for debugging.

dumpavail.name: dumpavail
dumpavail.description: Dumps a list of all available packages from the cache in a format similar to the `dpkg` status file. This output can be parsed by other tools or used to check the universe of installable packages.

unmet.name: unmet
unmet.description: Shows a summary of unmet dependencies in the system. This lists dependencies that are required by installed or available packages but are not currently satisfiable by any installable package. Useful for diagnosing broken package states.

showauto.name: showauto
showauto.description: Lists packages that were automatically installed as dependencies of other packages (i.e., marked as 'auto'). This can be run with `grep` to check if a specific package is auto-installed.

showsrc.name: showsrc
showsrc.description: Shows information about source packages. This is similar to `apt-cache show` but for source packages, listing details like the source package name, version, maintainer, and binary packages it builds.

gencaches.name: gencaches
gencaches.description: Creates the APT package cache. This is equivalent to running `apt-get update`, as it fetches the latest package lists from repositories and builds the local cache. Requires superuser privileges.

no_flags.output: Standard help information for the command.

search.output:
apache2 - Apache HTTP Server
nginx - small, powerful, scalable web/proxy server
lighttpd - fast, secure web server

show.output:

xvfb.output: The command runs internally to generate a PostScript file in a virtual X environment. Output is a file, not terminal text.

unmet.output: If no unmet dependencies exist, the command produces no output.

showsrc.output:
Package: nginx
Binary: nginx, nginx-doc, nginx-common, nginx-full, nginx-light ... (source package details)

gencaches.output: Standard output from updating the package lists (similar to apt-get update).

commands.name: apt-add-repository
commands.description: Adds external APT repository definitions to the system's software sources. This command manages repository entries in files under /etc/apt/sources.list.d/ and /etc/apt/sources.list, allowing users to install software from third-party repositories not included in the default Ubuntu/Debian archives. It can handle both PPA (Personal Package Archive) shortcuts (like 'ppa:user/repo') and full deb line repository URLs. After adding a repository, it typically updates the package cache automatically.

help.name: Help
help.description: Displays a help message with usage information and available options.

remove.name: Remove Repository
remove.description: Removes the specified repository from the system's software sources instead of adding it.

update.name: Update Package Cache
update.description: Runs 'apt-get update' after adding or removing the repository to refresh the package list. This is the default behavior.

no_update.name: Do Not Update
no_update.description: Prevents automatic running of 'apt-get update' after the operation. The repository is added or removed, but the package cache is not refreshed.

enable_source.name: Enable Source Packages
enable_source.description: Also downloads the source packages for the repository by adding a 'deb-src' line in addition to the standard 'deb' line.

component.name: Override Component
component.description: Overrides the default component (often 'main') used when expanding a PPA shortcut. The component is specified as an extra argument after the repository.

keyserver.name: Specify Keyserver
keyserver.description: Specifies a custom keyserver URL to use for retrieving the GPG key associated with the repository, instead of the default keyserver.

dry_run.name: Dry Run
dry_run.description: Performs a simulation of the actions without actually making any changes to the system. Useful for testing.

no_flags.output: Output is standard repository addition confirmation and apt-get update output.

remove.output: Output is standard repository removal confirmation and apt-get update output.

no_update.output: Repository is added but package cache is not updated.

enable_source.output: Adds both 'deb' and 'deb-src' lines for the repository.

component.command: sudo apt-add-repository -c contrib 'deb http://archive.example.com/debian stable main contrib'
component.output: Adds the repository with the 'contrib' component explicitly set.

keyserver.command: sudo apt-add-repository --keyserver hkp://keyserver.ubuntu.com:80 'deb http://packages.example.com/repo stable main'
keyserver.output: Adds repository, fetching GPG key from the specified keyserver.

dry_run.output: Simulation output showing what would be done without making changes.
